posts.title: The Film
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[["html",{"html":"

About the Film

In 1997, nelson de witt, a 16-year-old adoptee from Boston, Massachusetts, discovered that he had been identified as one Roberto Coto, an infant who disappeared in 1982 after a deadly government raid on three guerrilla safe houses in Tegucigalpa, Honduras.

The raid rescued a kidnapped businessman and also resulted in the disappearance of a dozen Salvadoran revolutionaries, including Roberto’s biological mother, Ana Milagro Escobar. Today, a generation after one of the bloodiest conflicts of the Cold War, the wounds of the Civil War in El Salvador are still open and the truth about them has been obscured.

Nelson/Roberto has determined that sharing his search for the truth about his story is his way of making a difference. At the heart of Nelson/Roberto’s search is the simple belief that finding what makes us all alike—or connected—can change the world.

Sign up for updates

A Timeline for the Film

JULY 1990- Cabin 23, Camp Frank A. Day.
East Brookfield, Massachusetts
MARCH 2011- Día Dedicado a las Niñas y Niños Desaparecidos.
Anfiteatro del CIFCO, San Salvador, El Salvador
MAY 2012- Robert H. Kirschner, M.D., Memorial Human Rights Lecture Series
Chicago, Illinois
AUGUST 2013- John Younger’s Wedding
Boston, Massachusetts

1990 – Summer

Our journey together started many years before the cameras started rolling. John (age 18) was Nelson’s (age 8) first counselor at a YMCA summer camp in Western Massachusetts. Funny enough, we even shared a bunk together

2010 – Winter

After reconnecting on Facebook in 2008, John began reading Nelson’s blog Ana’s Miracle to find out why Nelson now referred to himself as Nelson/Roberto. Drawn in by Nelson’s passion to share his family’s story, we began working together after John offered to share his background as a TV/Film Producer to help in any way he could.

2010 – Fall

We launched a fundraising campaign via the crowd sourcing website Kickstarter that would allow us to begin telling the story in the form of a documentary. By the last week of our 8 week campaign, we had raised only 30% of our $15,000 goal when something amazing happened: we closed a $9,000 gap to successfully fund the project in six days and with the backing of 170 total supporters!

2011 – Spring

Nelson was invited to participate in an historic commemoration of El Salvador’s Day of the Disappeared Children and we decided this event would be a great place to begin our documentary process. During our 10-day trip to El Salvador, we interviewed several members of Nelson’s family and the other disappeared children, met the President of El Salvador, and traveled out to the Department of Chalatenango, the former Conflict Zone, to meet Suyapa Serrano Cruz, a woman who one day will be listed in textbooks about Latin America as a Civil Rights Hero. It was an amazing experience.

2011 – Fall

While Nelson was in LA, to shoot for the film, we were invited to KPCC Southern California Public Radio to share clips from the documentary. During the event Nelson was interviewed by several members of the press which eventually led to an article in the Huffington Post.

2012 – Spring

After members of the Kirschner family read the Huffington Post article Nelson, John, and Margaret Ward were invited to speak at the U. Chicago Robert H. Kirschner, M.D., Memorial Human Rights Lecture Series. John shared an 8-minute extended preview of the film, Margaret read from her book Missing Mila, Finding Family and Nelson spoke about the impact Dr. Kirschner had on his life.

Release

The film is still in production, but you can sign up for updates to receive news about it’s relaese. We want the project to help in the search for the at least 500 disappeared children who are still missing today.

Listen to the podcast

Every week John and Nelson release an episode of the Inside the Journey podcast. We talk about the latest developments with the film and bring in guests related to the project.

You can subscribe to the podcast on iTunes, Stitcher Radio, or SoundCloud. New episodes come out every Sunday, so make sure to follow along.

Check out the latest episode >

posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[["html",{"html":"

Press Links

The Revelation

BOLDEDITION.COM – Clarence Smith Jr. for BOLD Edition

JULY 13,2011
On May 10th, 1983, Thomas de Witt and Margaret Ward received a late night phone call. The voice at the other end of the line said there was an older child available for adoption. The boy’s background was completely unknown—his real name, when he was born or even where he was born. The voice also declared they had until 10AM the next morning to decide if they would adopt the child. Twenty days later in Honduras, de Witt and Ward officially became the boy’s parents. They named him Nelson.

Sparse details related to their son’s history were not the only unusual circumstances regarding his adoption. de Witt and Ward’s FBI clearances—a necessary aspect of the adoption process—were expedited. They were provided a lawyer. The wife of the United States ambassador to Honduras, Mrs. Negroponte, shepherded the adoption. The necessity for a rushed delivery of the small boy to de Witt and Ward were never explained to them. When they left Honduras and touched down in the United States, the details were insignificant. Nelson de Witt was officially their son.

Read More…

‘Identifying Nelson’: El Salvador Born, U.S. Man Searched For His Roots

HUFFINGTONPOST.COM – Jorge Luis Macias for Latino Voices

November 03,2011
PASADENA, Calif. — In the orphanage in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, the boy didn’t have a name or a history. He had been separated from his family by the death of his mother during the long civil war in El Salvador. Nobody claimed him. Eventually, he was adopted by a couple in Boston.
This is the story of Nelson De Witt, born Roberto Coto, removed as a 2-year-old child from his roots, his family and his native country.
Now, he has produced his own documentary, “Identifying Nelson,” to tell a tale that echoes the pain of many families torn apart by El Salvador’s 1980-1992 civil war. Some 70,000 people died and thousands more went missing, including hundreds of children who would be adopted by foreigners.

Read More…

Salvadoran group dogged in search for children missing years ago in civil war

LATIMES.COM – Ken Ellingwood for Los Angeles Times

JULY 13,2011
For many searching for loved ones, the only hope is a determined Salvadoran organization using detective work, modern tools such as Facebook and plenty of pluck to solve the wartime disappearances.

Reporting from Guarjila, El Salvador — Her name is Milagro, or it was before her mother’s heart broke into a million bits.
The girl was 4, dark-toned and skinny. On the day soldiers took her away, she wore a violet dress with short sleeves and tiny pleats. She had no shoes.
“They took my girl and said, ‘Go, old lady!'” recalled her mother, Enma Orellana. The woman ran in fear, looking back just once, when the girl cried, “Mama!”

Read More…

Other Links

Ana’s Miracle

A Family Blog – 2007 to 2011

Starting in 2007 several members of the extended family started recording their thoughts and memories online for all to read. The blog features posts from Margaret’s adopted son, Nelson and his birth sister, Eva, but also has posts from Margaret, her son Derek , and other members of Nelson’s birth family, including his brother Ernesto, and his cousin Mireya.

http://www.anasmiracle.com

Missing Mila, Finding Family

Written by Nelson’s adopted mother

Margaret E. Ward tells a poignant and compelling story of an international adoption and the astonishing revelations that emerged when Nelson’s birth family finally relocated him in 1997.

http://www.missingmila.com

Asociación Pro-Búsqueda de Niñas y Niños Desaparecidos

(Association Searching for Disappeared Girls and Boys)

A non-governmental grass-roots organization founded by Father Jon Cortina in 1994 and based in San Salvador that searches for children who disappeared during the Salvadoran Civil War (1980-1992). One of four human rights organizations involved in the search for Nelson/Roberto.

http://probusqueda.org.sv/

Physicians for Human Rights

(PHR)

PHR is a non-governmental organization that uses medicine and forensic science to investigate atrocities and human rights violations against individuals. It also advocates for human rights worldwide.  Based in Cambridge, Massachusetts, it was one of the four organizations that investigated Nelson/Roberto’s case and contacted the Ward/de Witt family in 1997.

http://physiciansforhumanrights.org

posts.title: Contact
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[["html",{"html":"

From The Filmmakers

Nelson de Witt / Roberto Coto

“ Since I first learned of my family’s story, that unforgettable August night, I knew someday I would share our story with the world. For me, this film is the beginning of that journey.

Growing up with two identities changed me. It made me feel like an outsider because I began to see the world differently than those around me.  What was normal for everyone else felt challenging to me and what seemed extraordinary to others became ordinary.  

When John and I started talking about making this documentary, I realized that in the film was a chance for me to find meaning in what happened, rediscover where I come from, and bring people into my world.

My family’s story runs through the heart of the Salvadoran Civil War. It is a story that most people, even in El Salvador, have no idea ever even happened. I want to change that. My efforts are dedicated to the memory of my mother, Ana Milagro Escobar, who disappeared with me in Tegucigalpa, Honduras in 1982.”

Visit Nelson’s website : http://www.nelsonroberto.com/

Email Nelson : nelson@identifyingnelson.com

John Younger

“My favorite explanation about the need to tell stories comes from the historian Wallace Stegner, who wrote, “Any people in a new land may be pardoned for being solicitous about their history; they create it, in a sense, by remembering it.” While Stegner was speaking about 19th Century Mormon Pioneers, I’ve always felt that his words apply equally well to anyone whose truth doesn’t fit neatly into a familiar little box.

I met Nelson as his counselor at a YMCA summer camp in Western Massachusetts. I was trying to keep up with a cabin full of Mighty Midgets before heading off to my first year of college. He was a happy and determined 8-year-old who already was showing his proclivity for being a snappy dresser. One memory that has stuck with me of Nelson the camper is from the Family Visiting Day, when his younger brother Derek grasped around one of Nelson’s fingers and seemed to never let go from the minute he arrived until it was time to leave.

After reconnecting with him on Facebook recently, I started reading Nelson’s blog, Ana’s Miracle, to find out why he now referred to himself by two names, Nelson/Roberto. His blog posts and videos about life with his family revealed an absolute determination to share that story. It’s a story that deals with subjects like war, adoption, family, and identity. It’s a story that recalls events which are larger-than-life and twist in unexpected ways. But most of all, it’s a story about what makes us alike or connected, which is something I began learning about from Nelson and his family a long time ago.”

Visit John’s website : http://www.johnfyounger.net/

Email John : john@identifyingnelson.com

Contact us

General inquiries: info@identifyingnelson.com

Press inquiries: press@identifyingnelson.com

Speaking engagements: bookings@identifyingnelson.com

Website: webmaster@identifyingnelson.com

posts.title: Our new website is here!
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[["html",{"html":"

I’m very excited to announce that the new website for Identifying Nelson/Buscando a Roberto is here! So what’s new about it? Well… actually not much, just now the site is integrated with WordPress. This means we will be able to update all of you more often about the progress of the film.

A little bit of history.

The site for Identifying Nelson/Buscando a Roberto was created by a friend of mine named Cedric. Cedric and I met during my second Kickstarter campaign to write the e-book A Kickstarter’s Guide to Kickstarter.

Cedric was one of my first backers and messaged to say how he much he liked the project. We got to talking and realized that Cedric had worked on a letter writing campaign for amnesty international in the early 90’s, in an effort to end the civil war in El Salvador.

Cedric who has a background in painting, music, publishing, and web design offered to help create a website for our film. While he was at it, he also created a website for my mother’s book Missing Mila, Finding Family. Both my mother and I love the way the websites turned out.

You can check out more of Cedric’s work at his website DISCREETCASES.com.

So what exactly did you do?

Well to tell you the truth, not much. Cedric did most of the hard work for us. All I did was convert his design into a basic WordPress theme.

If you have ever played around with WordPress you know that creating your own theme can be a little tricky. However, after a few weeks of hacking I got it to work. There may still be a few design flaws but we should have it smoothed out soon.

Why do you need a WordPress site?

For those of you who have no idea what I mean when I saw “WordPress,” it is a piece of software that lets you easily update a website. You have the ability to write updates (like this one) and post them to your site. The WordPress software is used by a whooping 17.7% of all sites on the internet, and now ours does too!

WordPress will allow us to communicate with you a lot more frequently. It will also allow us to host our very own Podcast about the making of our documentary film. (A Podcast is an internet radio show that anyone can produce.) More about that to come!

How do I stay updated?

I know what you are thinking: All of this sounds great but how am I going to keep up with everything? Well you have a number of options. You can follow us on Facebook or on Twitter or you can sign up for our email newsletter.

The Identifying Nelson/Buscando a Roberto newsletter goes out about once or twice a month. It contains only the most important news about the film and is the best way to keep updated about our progress. You can sign up here.

posts.title: Episode #01: Why are we making this film?
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[["html",{"html":"

Welcome to the first episode of the Inside the Journey podcast. John and I are so very excited to be sharing this with you today.

Since the completion of our Kickstarter project in the fall of 2010 we have been working hard to bring our vision to life. It has been a long road but we are getting ready to release the film this fall.

As part of this effort, John and I decided that we would launch a podcast to keep everyone up to date with what is going on. So much has happened with the project already but we don’t always get to share it. We have done our best to keep everyone updated via Kickstarter and Facebook but we both felt we could do better.

About the podcast

Our goal is to give you a look at what is going on behind the scenes with the film and to explore the very complicated topic of the war in El Salvador. Besides talking about the film we want to bring you interviews with people who lived through and were effected by the civil war in El Salvador. John and I feel that this podcast will play a very important role as we get set for the fall release.

Since we are just starting, the Podcast is not available on iTunes but we will be adding it shortly. New episodes will come out every Sunday, so make sure to follow along.

You can follow us on Facebook or on Twitter or you can sign up for our email newsletter.

The Identifying Nelson/Buscando a Roberto newsletter goes out about once or twice a month. It contains only the most important news about the film and is the best way to keep updated about our progress. You can sign up here.

Help spread the word

Whenever you launch something into the world it can be incredibly difficult to get traction. If this project is meaningful to you in any way, we hope that you will share it.

We know you are busy, so we created a webpage that will let you easily share the podcast on Facebook and Twitter. If you’re not into social media you can always forward this email.

Share the Inside the Journey Podcast.

Show Notes

Intro:

Welcome to the first episode of the Inside the Journey podcast. I’m Nelson de Witt. I’m John Younger and we are working on the Documentary film Identifying Nelson/Buscando a Roberto, a film about El Salvador’s disappeared children.

Background (5 Min):

We thought we would provide you with a little background information about the war in El Salvador and who the disappeared children are. El Salvador, which is a tiny country in Central America the size and population of Massachusetts, was engaged in a bloody 13 year civil war. During that time over 900 children were either lost or stolen. They are called the Disappeared.

  • 921 reports of children who went missing
  • 382 Solved cases
  • 235 Reunions

Discussion:

For the first episode we want to talk about how we got involved in this project and what it means to us now.

Questions for John: (by Nelson)

  • Why did John get involved?
  • Why did you get into TV/Film production?
  • What does this project mean to you?
  • What do you want to get out of it?

Image of Derek and Nelson

Questions for Nelson: (by John)

  • What has doing this meant to you?
  • What do you most want people to know about your story?
  • And a few more questions that I’m not telling 🙂

Outro:

Thats our show!

  • You can subscribe to the podcast by going to www.identifyingnelson.com
  • We would love to hear from you. Leave us a comment on Facebook.com/IdentifyingNelson
  • Or if you want say something more personal email us at podcast@identifyingnelson.com
  • Tune in next week: We will be talking about some of our personal highlights working on this film.

Links:

  • Ana’s Miracle Blog
  • Identifying Nelson Website
  • Pro-busqueda
  • Camp Frank A. Day

Credits:

  • Hosts – Nelson de Witt & John Younger
  • Producer – Mark Kornweibel
  • Editor – Nelson de Witt

Episode #4: What’s next for the film?

Guest(s): 05/19/13
Description: In the fourth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson talk about what’s next for the film. They cover the next six months leading up to a 2nd crowd-funding campaign and beyond.

Episode #5: Finding Family with Margaret E. Ward. (Part 1)

Date: 06/2/13
Guest(s): Margaret E. Ward
Description: In the fifth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson interview Margaret E. Ward author of Missing Mila, Finding Family. We talk about her book, what went into writing it, and what has happened since it’s release.

Episode #6: Finding Family with Margaret E. Ward. (Part 2)

Date: 06/9/13
Guest(s): Margaret E. Ward
Description: In the sixth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson continue their talk with Margaret E. Ward author of Missing Mila, Finding Family. She talks about the history of El Salvador and her thoughts on the film.

Episode #7: The Origins of Pro-B with Ralph Sprenkels (Part 1)

Date: 06/16/13
Guest(s): Ralph Sprenkels
Description: In the seventh episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson talk with Ralph Sprenkels about the origins of Pro-Busqueda. In part one we talk about early years of the war and the work of father Jon Cortina.

Episode #8: The Origins of Pro-B with Ralph Sprenkels (Part 2)

Date: 06/23/13
Guest(s): Ralph Sprenkels
Description: In the eighth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson continue their talk with Ralph Sprenkels. This week we’ll talk about how that work led to Pro Busqueda’s ongoing search for children who disappeared in the Salvadoran Civil War.

Episode #9: Living with two identities with Nelson de Witt

Date: 06/30/13
Guest(s): Nelson de Witt
Description: In the third episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John interviews Nelson talk about living with two identities. Nelson shares his feelings of being torn between two worlds and how hard it can be at times.

Episode #10: Why should we care? With Derek de Witt

Date: 07/07/13
Guest(s): Derek de Witt
Description: In the tenth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson talk with Nelson’s brother Derek about his experiences. He shares a poem he wrote and talks about why we should care about the war in El Salvador.

Episode #11: The unforeseen consequences of our decisions with Danii

Date: 07/14/13
Guest(s): Danii Sancho
Description: In the eleventh episode of the Inside the Journey Nelson interviews his niece Daniela Sancho Coto. She talks about the unforeseen consequences of our decisions and growing up with an uncle who isn’t always there.

Episode #12: Recap Episode (Part 1)

Date: 07/21/13
Description: In the twelfth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson reflect on their conversations with previous guests. In part one they talk about interviewing Margaret E. Ward, author of Missing Mila, Finding Family, and Ralph Sprenkels the lead investigator on Nelson’s case.

Episode #13: Recap Episode (Part 2)

Date: 07/28/13
Description: In the thirteenth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson reflect on their conversations with previous guests. In part two they talk about living with two identities and their interviews with Derek and Danii.

Episode #14: Misfit Invasion, feedback from Fargo.

Date: 08/04/13
Guest(s): Jackie Lea Shelley, Deb Brown, and Sue Anne Reed
Description: In the fourteenth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast Nelson talks to the Misfits about their take on our film. Deb, Jackie, and Sue Ann comment on what they saw in Fargo.

Episode #15: Nelson’s Adoption Story (Part 1)

Date: 08/11/13
Guest(s): Thomas de Witt and Margaret E. Ward
Description: Imagine getting a phone call at 9:30pm notifying you that a child has just become available to adopt. However, you are given no photo, no history, and you have until 10am the next morning to decided. That is just a small part of the story behind Nelson’s adoption

In the fifteenth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast Nelson’s parents tell the story of how he was adopted. It is filled with mystery and drama as Tom & Margaret take a leap of faith for an unknown child.

Episode #16: Nelson’s Adoption Story (Part 2)

Date: 08/18/13
Guest(s): Thomas de Witt and Margaret E. Ward
Description: Imagine getting a phone call at 9:30pm notifying you that a child has just become available to adopt. However, you are given no photo, no history, and you have until 10am the next morning to decided. That is just a small part of the story behind Nelson’s adoption

In the fifteenth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast Nelson’s parents continue the story of how he was adopted.. It is filled with mystery and drama as Tom & Margaret take a leap of faith for an unknown child.

Episode #17: What can we learn from this story? With Nelson’s siblings

Date: 08/25/13
Guest(s): Derek de Witt, Eva Coto, Ernesto Coto
Description: In the seventeenth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast Nelson talk with his siblings about what life lessons they have learned. Derek, Ernesto and Eva share their thoughts on faith, their grand mother, and the meaning of family.

Episode #18: The art of storytelling with Clarence Smith Jr.

Date: 09/01/13
Guest(s): Clarence Smith Jr.
Description: In the eighteenth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast, Nelson talks with Clarence Smith Jr. about his online portfolio BOLD Edition. Clarence shares his thoughts about the process and challenges of telling a great story.

Episode #19: Business Plan Edition

Date: 09/08/13
Guest(s): N/A
Description: In the nineteenth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson talk about their plans to release the film in early 2014. They share some big announcements including The Advocate Experience, a way for you to see the film as it’s being developed.

Episode #20: Fear and filmmaking

Date: 09/15/13
Guest(s): N/A
Description: In the 20th episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson talk about the fear and anxiety that comes from making art. They share what they are scared of, and how they deal with those feelings.

Episode #21: Understanding the Salvadoran Conflict

Date: 09/22/13
Guest(s): N/A
Description: In the twenty first episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson share media resources that have helped them better understand the Salvadoran conflict. Making sense of war is always difficult, and these recourses help demonstrate the devastating impact of bad foreign policies on individual lives.

Episode #22: Washing Elephants

Date: 09/29/13
Guest(s): N/A
Description: In the 22nd episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson talk about facing criticism and addressing the Elephant in the room. They review last weeks NPR article and talk about the editorial challenges they face.

Episode #23: Films that inspire us

Date: 10/06/13
Guest(s): N/A
Description: In the 23rd episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson talk about three films that have inspired them. Each film breaks down a complex story to reveal a deeper, and not very well understood truth.

Episode #24: What’s our movement?

Date: 10/13/13
Guest(s): N/A
Description: In the 24th episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson talk about movements. The explore how movements start and what they hope to accomplish with the film.

Episode #25: Getting to know Nelson’s Siblings

Date: 10/20/13
Guest(s): N/A
Description: In the 25th episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John interviews Nelson and his siblings. They each share a part of the story that was important to them.

Episode #26: Unforeseen impact

Date: 10/20/13
Guest(s): N/A
Description: In the 26th episode of the Inside the Journey podcast we continue John’s interview with Nelson and his siblings. We talk about the unforeseen impact of being reunited and how it changed Eva and Ernesto.

Episode #27: Reactions from Wells

Date: 11/3/13
Guest(s): Margaret E. Ward
Description: In the 27th episode of the Inside the Journey podcast Nelson sits down with his mother, Margaret E. Ward, to talk about their event at Wells College. They talk about the audience’s reaction, questions from students and the challenges of telling a balanced story.

Episode #28: Impact vs Acclaim

Date: 11/10/13
Guest(s): N/A
Description: In the 28th episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson talk about their decision to remain independent and some of the trade-offs. They talk about the challenges of going to film festivals such as Sundance and how sometimes the best thing to do is pick yourself.

Episode #29: Balancing two lives with Peter Cassidy-Sibrian (Part 1)

Date: 11/17/13
Guest(s): Peter Cassidy-Sibrian
Description: John & Nelson talk with Peter Cassidy-Sibrian about reconnecting with his birth family and his experiences visiting El Salvador. He shares some memorable stories about his time with Father John Cortina.

Episode #30: Balancing two lives with Peter Cassidy-Sibrian (Part 2)

Date: 11/24/13
Guest(s): Peter Cassidy-Sibrian
Description: John & Nelson continue their talk with Peter Cassidy-Sibrian about reconnecting with his birth family and his experiences visiting El Salvador. He talks about the challenges of balancing family and people’s perceptions about the war.

Episode #31: Catching up with Pro-B

Date: 12/1/13
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John & Nelson talk with Yolaina who works at Pro-Búsqueda to help family’s through the reunion process. We talk about the work that Pro-b is doing and the challenges of being reunited with a family you’ve never met.

Episode #31: 16 years, a look back with Tom & Margaret

Date: 12/8/13
Guest(s): Tom de Witt & Margaret E. Ward
Description: Nelson talks with his adoptive parents Tom de Witt and Margaret War about the past 16 years. They share how meaningful it has been to develop a relationship with members of Nelson’s biological family.

Episode #33: 16 Years, a look back with Derek & Ernesto

Date: 12/15/13
Guest(s): Derek & Ernesto
Description: Nelson talks with his brothers Derek and Ernesto about our 16 year reunion. Ernesto gives us a glimpse into the experience of the birth family and Derek shares some old stories.

Episode #34: 16 Years, a look back with Nelson/Roberto

Date: 12/22/13
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John interviews Nelson about the 16th anniversary of when he was reunited with his family. They share some memories from 2013.

Episode #35: We lived

Date: 1/12/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John & Nelson work through the creative process as they search for language that will tie together scene two. Nelson shares some very personal feelings about what it means to share his story.

Episode #36: Reactions to A Promise to the Dead

Date: 1/19/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John & Nelson talk about the film, “A Promise to the Dead: The Exile Journey of Ariel Dorfman.” They share their reactions and talk it relates back to Identifying Nelson/Buscando a Roberto.

Episode #37: What’s in your bag?

Date: 1/26/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John & Nelson talk about the equipment they use to film and how it impacted the interviews. They discuss the benefits of the equipment’s small size and how allowed them record very intimate interviews with their subjects.

Episode #38: Forced disappearances in the context of Latin America

Date: 2/2/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John & Nelson talk about the phenomenon of forced disappearances throughout Latin America. Most films, books, and articles talk about the disappearances in El Salvador with out looking at countries like Argentina, Chili, and Guatemala who all had similar pasts.

Episode #39: Finding what makes us alike

Date: 2/9/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John & Nelson talk about the lessons we hope people will take away from our film. They talk about the mindset which allowed these atrocities to happen, and contrast them with the cost of war on an individual/family level.

Episode #40: Act III, FMLN Arena

Date: 2/16/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John & Nelson talk about Act III of their film, “FMLN Arena.” They share memories from the 2011 Day of The Disappeared, which is at the heart of the Act.

Episode #41: Historical Memory

Date: 2/23/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John & Nelson talk about the concept of historical memory and what it means to the country of El Salvador. They also talk about the lack of historical memory in the United States.

Episode #42: Life as a Salvadoran Adoptee with Marla Roach

Date: 3/2/14
Guest(s): Marla Roach
Description: John & Nelson talk to Marla Roach who is a Salvadoran Adoptee looking for her birth family. She talks about meeting other adoptees and her slow realization that her adoption was not what it seamed.

Episode #43: What’s our crowd-funding story?

Date: 3/9/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John & Nelson talk about what is at the core of Nelson’s story as they work on a narrative for their crowd-funding campaign. They explore the themes of connection, identity, and how they can change the way we view the world.

Episode #44: Searching Sisters with Ana and Isabel (Part 1)

Date: 3/16/14
Guest(s): Ana and Isabel
Description: John & Nelson talk to Ana and Isabel two Salvadoran adoptees from the New England area who went looking for their birth family. They share their adoption story, talk about the search, and some of the challenges they have faced.

Episode #45: Searching Sisters with Ana and Isabel (Part 2)

Date: 3/23/14
Guest(s): Ana and Isabel
Description: John & Nelson talk to Ana and Isabel two Salvadoran adoptees from the New England area who went looking for their birth family. They share their adoption story, talk about the search, and some of the challenges they have faced.

Episode #46: The President’s Speech

Date: 3/30/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: In order to commemorate El salvador’s Day of the Disappeared, March 29th, John & Nelson are airing a speech made in 2011 by former President Mauricio Funes. While the speech is in spanish they provide commentary on it for our english speaking audience.

El Discurso de Conmemoración del Día Dedicado a las Niñas y Niños Desaparecidos, Mauricio Funes en el año 2011, donde se disculpa por las atrocidades cometidas durante la Guerra civil.

Episode #47: What does El Salvador’s recent election mean for the Disappeared?

Date: 4/6/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John & Nelson speculate about the impact of El Salvador’s recent election for the disappeared and the country’s amnesty laws.

Episode #48: Romanticizing Adoption and Reunion with Mila

Date: 4/13/14
Guest(s): Mila Konomos
Description: Nelson talks to Mila Konomos a Korean American adoptee who wrote about the challenges of reuniting with your birth family. They discuss the similarities and differences between their stories and the role identity and culture has to play in adoption.

Episode #49: Race, culture, and identity

Date: 4/20/14
Guest(s): Lindsay Welch
Description: Nelson & Lindsay talk about race and culture and how that relates to identity. Nelson shares stories where his race and culture were out of alignment and how that shaped his world view.

Episode #50: How our film project got started

Date: 4/27/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: In honor of the first full year of the podcast John & Nelson talk about the ebook that started it all. Back in 2010 John discovered an ebook that Nelson wrote as part of his website Ana’s Miracle.

Episode #51: How the trip El Salvador effected us

Date: 5/4/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John & Nelson talk about how their perspectives have changed since their 2011 trip to El Salvador. Sometimes it takes a while to understand the impact of a trip of this magnitude.

Episode #52: Brainstorming future podcast topics

Date: 5/11/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: After doing 51 episodes one can start to feel like there is nothing left to talk about. So, John & Nelson take some time to brainstorm ideas and topics for future podcasts.

Episode #53: An important film update

Date: 5/18/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: In this short but important podcast John & Nelson talk about the latest developments of the film.

Episode #54: Remembering Mama Chila

Date: 5/25/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: Nelson/Roberto talks with his siblings about their grandmother Mama Chila, who became a surrogate mother to Eva and Ernesto. They talk about her influence on the family and how losing she losing her own mother motivated Mama Chila to take care them.

Episode #55: Catching up with the Advocates

Date: 6/1/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: In a “live” episode from Fargo, ND Nelson talks with Weston and Louise about being part of The Advocate Experience. They share feedback about the program and offer some ideas about how to get the film out into the world.

Episode #56: Current events in El Salvador

Date: 6/8/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John & Nelson talk about the rise of gang violence in El Salvador after the country’s new president Sánchez Cerén took office.

Episode #57: Camp Frank A. Day Edition With John, Josh, and Curtis.

Date: 6/15/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: Nelson interviews three of his former camp counselors John Younger, Curtis Fazen, and Josh Lieberman. They share memories of Nelson as a camper and what meeting his birth family meant to them.

Episode #58: Invisible Progress

Date: 6/22/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: Nelson does a solo podcast from the road and talks about the idea of “invisible progress.” Long term projects can be though because you work for months with out seeing results, then in all of a sudden everything comes together.

Episode #59: Forensic Anthropology in Guatemala with Stefan Schmitt

Date: 6/22/14
Guest(s): Stefan Schmitt
Description: John & Nelson talk with the director of PHR’s International Forensic Program Stefan Schmitt about his life and work in Guatemala. This is the first of a multipart episode.

Episode #60: Violence in Guatemala during the 80’s with Stefan Schmitt

Date: 7/6/14
Guest(s): Stefan Schmitt
Description: John & Nelson talk with the director of PHR’s International Forensic Program Stefan Schmitt about the violence in Guatemala during the 80’s.

Episode #61: Trying to make sense of war with Stefan Schmitt

Date: 7/13/14
Guest(s): Stefan Schmitt
Description: John & Nelson talk with the director of PHR’s International Forensic Program Stefan Schmitt about how events in Latin America are tied to Vietnam and Iraq. They try to make sense of wars past and present in order to find a little bit of hope.

Episode #62: The Moakley Report with Jim McGovern

Date: 7/20/14
Guest(s): Jim McGovern on Wikipedia
Description: John & Nelson talk to Congressman Jim McGovern about his experiences in El Salvador and the work he did on The Moakley report.

Episode #63: Amnesty in El Salvador with Congressman Jim McGovern

Date: 7/27/14
Guest(s): Jim McGovern on Wikipedia
Description: John & Nelson talk to Congressman Jim McGovern about his modern day El Salvador it’s struggle to find justice.

Episode #64: Baby Mila with Eva Coto

Date: 8/3/14
Guest(s): Eva Coto
Description: Nelson talk with his sister Eva about her new born baby Mila. They discuss the significance of the name Mila and what legacy means to them.

Episode #65: Life on the Border with Kathryn Ferguson

Date: 8/10/14
Guest(s): Kathryn Ferguson
Description: John & Nelson talk to Kathryn Ferguson about her work with Tucson Samaritans. For the past 10 years Kathryn has been providing humanitarian aid to immigrants trying to cross the US border near Tuscon.

Episode #66: Summer Recap Episode

Date: 8/17/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John & Nelson take time to discuss the highlights of their interviews with Stefan Schmitt and Congressman Jim McGovern.

Episode #67: Activism for El Salvador with Rob McAndrews

Date: 8/24/14
Guest(s): Robert K McAndrews
Description: Nelson talks to Rob McAndrews, a professor at Salem State, who has done a lot work in El Salvador and with the Salvadoran community.

Episode #68: The Difficult Truth with Robert McAndrews

Date: 8/31/14
Guest(s): Robert K McAndrews
Description: Nelson continues his talk with Rob McAndrews, a professor at Salem State, who has done a lot work in El Salvador and with the Salvadoran community.

Episode #69: Creating a compelling narrative with Margaret E. Ward

Date: 9/7/14
Guest(s): Margaret E. Ward
Description: Nelson talks with his mother, Margaret E. Ward, about the challenges of creating a compelling narrative from our incredibly complex family history.

Episode #70: How does one define justice?

Date: 9/21/14
Guest(s): Lindsay Welch
Description: John & Nelson talk with Lindsay about challenges of defining justice. Often we are able to determine that an injustice has accrued, but it can be much harder to determine how to make up or correct for that injustice.

Episode #71: The Yellow Book

Date: 10/5/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John & Nelson talk about the discovery of a Salvadoran military document called The Yellow Book. It is an intelligence document that was created in 1987 which contains the names and pictures of individuals who were considered “enemies” of the state.

Episode #72: Speaking at Yale

Date: 10/19/14
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John talks with Nelson about his recent trip to Yale University to talk with the Salvadoran student group.

Episode #73: What does it mean to be Salvadoran?

Date: 11/2/14
Guest(s): Association of Salvadoreños at Yale Undergraduate
Description: Nelson talks with four students from the Association of Salvadoreños at Yale Undergraduate. They talk about juggling multiple identities and the contradictions that come with those identities.

Episode #74: The Unfinished Sentences Project

Date: 11/16/14
Guest(s): Phil Neff & Mina Manuchehri
Description: John & Nelson talk with Phil Neff and Mina Manuchehri about The Unfinished Sentences Project and their work on The Yellow Book. Phil and Mina explain how they have used Freedom of Information requests to obtain classified documents which help form a picture of how the Salvadoran military targeted civilians.

Episode #75: Unnecessary Hurt with Julie “JC” Miller

Date: 11/30/14
Guest(s): Julie “JC” Miller
Description: A conversation with Julie “JC” Miller, a Salvadoran adoptee, about her search, the importance of owning the process, and some helpful resources.

Episode #76: The Power of a Global Movement with Dr. Angelina Snodgrass Godoy

Date: 11/30/14
Guest(s): Angelina Snodgrass Godoy
Description: A conversation with Angelina Snodgrass Godoy about leading The Unfinished Sentences Project, and how she got involved with human rights work in Central America.

Episode #77: 2014 Recap and a look ahead

Date: 1/18/15
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John and Nelson take a look back at the progress made in 2014, and talk about what’s next for the film in 2015.

Episode #78: A Deeper Look at El Salvador with Jorge Cuéllar

Date: 2/1/15
Guest(s): Jorge E. Cuéllar
Description: A conversation about the history of El Salvador with Jorge E. Cuéllar, a PhD Candidate at Yale University. While the film and podcast primary look at El Salvador’s history over the past 30 years, Jorge provides us with deep picture of El Salvador’s past and explains what being Salvadoran means to him.

Episode #79: In the news, a few great articles to read

Date: 2/15/15
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John and Nelson talk about three articles that directly and indirectly related to El Salvador and how different groups of people deal will collective trauma.

Episode #80: Understanding The US Boarder Crisis with Prof. Aviva Chomsky

Date: 3/1/15
Guest(s): Aviva Chomsky
Description: A conversation about the 2014 US boarder crisis, with professor Aviva Chomsky. Professor Chomsky helps us understand the influx of Central American youths, by looking at the complicated and often misunderstood history of the region.

Episode #81: Gathering Testimony in El Salvador With Emma and Vincent

Date: 3/29/15
Guest(s): Emma Mahboub and Vincent Lee
Description: A conversation with Emma Mahboub and Vincent Lee, two students who are part of the Unfinished Sentences Task Force that recently went to El Salvador to record testimony of the disappeared and their families.

Episode #82: Where have we been?

Date: 7/26/15
Guest(s): N/A
Description: John and Nelson talk about what they have been up to over the past several months. They share an update about the film, podcast, and the newly formed Mama Chila Foundation.

Episode #83: Experiencing War with Philippe Bourgois

Date: 9/6/15
Guest(s): Philippe Bourgois
Description: A conversation about the Salvadoran Civil War with Philippe Bourgois. Philippe describes his time in Central America as a graduate student and how he got caught up in a firefight when the Salvadoran military raided a rural village.

Episode #84: Solidarity – Central America and SOA Watch with Arturo Viscarra

Date: 1/3/16
Guest(s): Arturo Viscarra
Description: A conversation with Arturo Viscara, the Advocacy Coordinator of SOA Watch. Arturo discusses his work with an organization that documents the atrocities linked to the School of the Americas, including a detailed discussion of the 2009 military coup in Honduras and how that event brought him to SOA Watch.

Show Title: What’s Next?

In the fourth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson talk about what’s next for the film. They cover the next six months leading up to a 2nd crowd-funding campaign and beyond.

About the podcast

Our goal with the podcast is to give you a look at what is going on behind the scenes with the film and to explore this very complicated issue.

You can subscribe to the podcast via iTunes. New episodes come out every Sunday, so make sure follow along.

You can follow us on Facebook or on Twitter or you can sign up for our email newsletter.

The Identifying Nelson/Buscando a Roberto newsletter goes out about once or twice a month. It contains only the most important news about the film and is the best way to keep updated about our progress. You can sign up here: http://eepurl.com/wvJEn.

Show Notes

Introduction

Welcome to the 4th episode of the Inside the Journey Podcast. I’m Nelson de Witt.

I’m John Younger.

And we are working on the documentary film Identifying Nelson/Buscando A Roberto.

Last week we launched the first episode of the podcast we just wanted to say thank you. This will be a little weird because you are hearing this two weeks (May 26th) later but it means a lot to us. We would love to hear form you and what you think about the podcast so far.

This week we are going to be talking about whats next for the film.

Discusion

What is next for the film?

  • Vision for the film
    • A high quality product
    • Producing a 45 minute piece (Act I)
    • What we want to accomplish
  • The next six months
    • Podcast
    • Finish editing
    • Wrapping up 1st campaign
    • 2nd Campaign
  • Beyond six months
    • Two more acts (II & III)
    • Where else we would like to go

Outro:

Thats our show!

  • You can subscribe to the podcast by going to www.identifyingnelson.com
  • We would love to hear form you. Leave us a comment on Facebook.com/IdentifyingNelson
  • Or if you want say something more personal email us at podcast@identifyingnelson.com
  • Tune in next Sunday: We will be talking with Nelson’s mom, Margaret E. Ward, about her book, Missing Mila, Finding Family.

Images/Video:

Links:

  • A Kickstarter’s Guide to Kickstarter

    • Our designer Cedric Victor

Credits:

  • Hosts – Nelson de Witt & John Younger
  • Producer – Mark Kornweibel
  • Editor – Nelson de Witt

Show Title: Finding Family with Margaret E. Ward.

In the fifth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson interview Margaret E. Ward author of Missing Mila, Finding Family. We talk about her book, what went into writing it, and what has happened since it’s release.

About the podcast

Our goal with the podcast is to give you a look at what is going on behind the scenes with the film and to explore this very complicated issue.

You can subscribe to the podcast in iTunes. New episodes come out every Sunday, so make sure follow along.

You can follow us on Facebook or on Twitter or you can sign up for our email newsletter.

The Identifying Nelson/Buscando a Roberto newsletter goes out about once or twice a month. It contains only the most important news about the film and is the best way to keep updated about our progress. You can sign up here: http://eepurl.com/wvJEn.

Show Notes

Introduction

Welcome to the Inside the Journey Podcast. This is episode #5 for Sunday, June 2nd 2013. I’m Nelson de Witt.

I’m John Younger.

And we are the creative masterminds behind the documentary film Identifying Nelson/Buscando A Roberto.

This week we have an extra special guest my mom! Well she’s not just my mom she is the author of Missing Mila, Finding Family: An International Adoption in the Shadow of the Salvadoran Civil War. She is a Professor of German, Emerita, who taught at Wellesley College in Wellesley Massachusetts from 1971 to 2010. I’m very pleased to introduce the one and only Margret Ward!

Discusion

  • Opening Welcome: Memorial Day weekend signifigance
  • Tell us about the book
    • Why did you write the book?
    • What was your experience in conducting your research and how the story unfolded?
    • Why did you start with Dalila’s hammock
  • What has happened since the book came out?
    • Events
    • Chicago

Outro:

Thats our show!

  • You can subscribe on iTunes.
  • We would love to hear form you. Leave us a comment on Facebook.com/IdentifyingNelson
  • Or if you want say something more personal email us at podcast@identifyingnelson.com
  • Tune in next Sunday, for part two of our talk with Margaret E. Ward.

posts.title: Episode #06: Finding Family with Margaret E. Ward (Part 2)

Show Title: Finding Family with Margaret E. Ward Part 2

In the sixth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson continue their talk with Margaret E. Ward author of Missing Mila, Finding Family. She talks about the history of El Salvador and her thoughts on the film.

About the podcast

Our goal with the podcast is to give you a look at what is going on behind the scenes with the film and to explore this very complicated issue.

You can subscribe to the podcast on iTunes and Stitcher Radio. New episodes come out every Sunday, so make sure follow along.

You can follow us on Facebook or on Twitter or you can sign up for our email newsletter.

The Identifying Nelson/Buscando a Roberto newsletter goes out about once or twice a month. It contains only the most important news about the film and is the best way to keep updated about our progress. You can sign up here: http://eepurl.com/wvJEn.

Show Notes

Introduction

Welcome to the Inside the Journey Podcast. This is episode #6 for Sunday, June 7th 2013. I’m Nelson de Witt.

I’m John Younger.

And we are the producer/director extraordinaire of the documentary film Identifying Nelson/Buscando A Roberto.

This week we have an extra special guest my mom! Well she’s not just my mom she is the author of Missing Mila, Finding Family: An International Adoption in the Shadow of the Salvadoran Civil War. She is a Professor of German, Emerita, who taught at Wellesley College in Wellesley Massachusetts from 1971 to 2010. I’m very pleased to introduce the one and only Margret Ward!

Discusion

  • a conversation about context for importance of including understanding of these events to historical memory … set context for violence of Civil War (i.e. setting the scene for a North American audience). complex, but also jarring to audience like scene from Argo. 2 readings- story of Mama Chila’s father’s death p. 116 The story of how Eva got her name. p 118.
  • conversation transitions to relevance to our world today. segue into Guatemala today. … the importance of looking back at these events, even all these years later. 3 discussion topics to bring in … This american life piece on Dos Erres and Oscar Alfredo Ramírez Castañeda … overturning of verdict from genocide trial of Rios Montt …Grandmothers of the Plaza de Mayo in Argentina.

Outro:

Thats our show!

  • You can subscribe to the podcast by going to www.identifyingnelson.com
  • We would love to hear form you. Leave us a comment on Facebook.com/IdentifyingNelson
  • Or if you want say something more personal email us at podcast@identifyingnelson.com
  • Tune in next Sunday,

Show Title: The Origins of Pro-B with Ralph Sprenkels

In the seventh episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson talk with Ralph Sprenkels about the origins of Pro-Busqueda. In part one we talk about early years of the war and the work of father Jon Cortina.

About the podcast

Our goal with the podcast is to give you a look at what is going on behind the scenes with the film and to explore this very complicated issue.

You can subscribe to the podcast on iTunes and Stitcher Radio. New episodes come out every Sunday, so make sure follow along.

You can follow us on Facebook or on Twitter or you can sign up for our email newsletter.

The Identifying Nelson/Buscando a Roberto newsletter goes out about once or twice a month. It contains only the most important news about the film and is the best way to keep updated about our progress. You can sign up here: http://eepurl.com/wvJEn.

Show Notes

Introduction

Welcome to the Inside the Journey Podcast. This is episode #7 for Sunday, June 16th 2013. I’m Nelson de Witt.

I’m John Younger.

And we are the producer/director extraordinaire of the documentary film Identifying Nelson/Buscando A Roberto.

Ralph Sprenkels has lived in El Salvador from 1992 until 2002, and from 2007 to 2010, working in the field of human rights, politics and international cooperation.

His publications include books and articles about El Salvador’s civil war, about missing children as a consequence of the armed conflict and about the human rights movement in El Salvador. In the Netherlands, he worked for the Interchurch Organization for Development Cooperation (ICCO) as a policy advisor on human rights issues until 2011. He is also a PhD candidate at Utrecht University. His most recent research concerns the role of war veterans in contemporary Salvadoran politics.

He participated in the mapping and documentation of human rights violations for the Truth Commission, in representation of Salvadoran civil society organizations.

Discussion

  • Origins and work of Pro Busqueda
    • How and why he got started with Pro Busqueda
    • Can you share a little about John Cortina: his story and your experiences working with him
  • Accomplishments and challenges of Pro B

Outro:

Show Title: The Origins of Pro-B with Ralph Sprenkels (Part 2)

In the eighth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson continue their talk with Ralph Sprenkels. In our previous episode, we discussed Father Jon Cortina and the work that he and Ralph did to help the people of Chalatenango, El Salvador participate in the Truth Commission Report, a process which documented atrocities of the war after the 1992 Peace Accords. This week we’ll talk about how that work led to Pro Busqueda’s ongoing search for children who disappeared in the Salvadoran Civil War.

Introduction to Ralph Sprenkels

Ralph Sprenkels has lived in El Salvador from 1992 until 2002, and from 2007 to 2010, working in the field of human rights, politics and international cooperation.

His publications include books and articles about El Salvador’s civil war, about missing children as a consequence of the armed conflict and about the human rights movement in El Salvador. In the Netherlands, he worked for the Interchurch Organization for Development Cooperation (ICCO) as a policy advisor on human rights issues until 2011. He is also a PhD candidate at Utrecht University. His most recent research concerns the role of war veterans in contemporary Salvadoran politics.

He participated in the mapping and documentation of human rights violations for the Truth Commission, in representation of Salvadoran civil society organizations. He was also the lead investigator in the case that reunited Nelson/Roberto’s family.

Show Title: Why should we care? With Derek de Witt

In the tenth episode of the Inside the Journey podcast John & Nelson talk with Nelson’s brother Derek about his experiences. He shares a poem he wrote and talks about why we should care about the war in El Salvador.

About the podcast

Our goal with the podcast is to give you a look at what is going on behind the scenes with the film and to explore this very complicated issue.

Show Notes

Introduction

Welcome to the Inside the Journey Podcast. This is episode #10 for Sunday, July 7th 2013. I’m Nelson de Witt.

I’m John Younger.

And we are the team behind the documentary film Identifying Nelson/Buscando A Roberto.

Before we introduce today’s guest I want to ask you for your feedback! We would love to know what is your favorite episode is and why?

I recently wrote post about why we should support and share our friend’s work that got a lot of traction. In it I argue that if you want to support your friends then you should comment and share their work online. It lets us know that people like what we are doing and it spreads the word.

Today’s guest is Nelson’s brother Derek de Witt. Derek is someone who was was not directly effected by the war but was impacted by it.

Discussion

  • What is your favorite episode? Why?
  • What do you remember about the reunion and that time period?
  • How has the war in El Salvador impacted you?
  • On a personal level what does it feel like to be part of this bigger family?
  • Why should anyone care? (John)

Show Title: The unforeseen consequences of our decisions with Danii

In the eleventh episode of the Inside the Journey podcast Nelson interviews his niece Daniela Sancho Coto. She talks about the unforeseen consequences of our decisions and growing up with an uncle who isn’t always there.

Show Notes

Introduction

Welcome to the Inside the Journey Podcast. This is episode #11 for Sunday, July 14th 2013. I’m Nelson de Witt.

Due to a scheduling conflict John Younger is out today.

And we are the team behind the documentary film Identifying Nelson/Buscando A Roberto.

Today’s guest flew all the way from Costa Rica just to be with us today. It is niece Daniela Sancho Coto. She is turning 15 in a few weeks. She is a high school student, an avid reader, and huge fan of twilight. Dani is joining us today to talk about her experiences growing up a generation removed from the violence in El Salvador.

Discussion

  • Have you listened to any of the podcast? What do you think so far?
  • You were born after the reunion. What has that been like for you?
  • Growing up did you ever hear any stories from the war?

posts.title: The Advocate Experience
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[["html",{"html":"

The Advocate Experience

A different way
to experience a
documentary film.

Don’t just watch it, be a part of it.

Apply here

Help launch a film that strives to gives voice to the voiceless.

By 1980 political turmoil in El Salvador unleashed a twelve-year civil war. During that conflict that resulted in 75,000 deaths, many children were violently separated from their families. Some were just lost in the chaos of war, but others were forcibly taken by members of the Armed Forces. Today they are called the “Disappeared Children of El Salvador. ” (Niñas y Niños Desaparecidos). With this film we want to give voice to the Disappeared and their families, and their ongoing struggle to find loved ones.

Being an advocate
is not just about advocacy.

You will get to see as we are working on it. You will get to see special behind the scenes material that won’t be in the film and won’t be shared publicly. Finally, you will be invited to special events like video hangouts and in person get togethers.

Not only will you see the film first, but you will help us shape it.

As an Advocate you will shape the film by providing feedback and helping spread the word. Feedback is an vital part of the creative process and your opinion will help make this the best film possible. When it’s time to launch your voice will be an important part in bringing others to the film.

Weekly updates, video chats, and more.

Advocates will received weekly emails about our process. These emails will have links, or pictures, or the latest scene that we are working on. We will hold a monthly video hang out where we can all get together and talk about the latest developments. There may also be a few other surprises along the way. 🙂

We are currently full, but you can still join the waiting list. Eventually we will invite more people, but at the moment we cannot say exactly when that will be.

Apply here

What to expect as a guest on Inside the Journey

How long it will take

This year we are production 20–30 minute episodes which are pre-recorded, edited, and released Sunday mornings. The recording usually last 30–45 minutes, but we schedule hour long blocks to give us some wiggle room. We will email you a link to the show when it is live.

You can join the recording from work or home as long as you have a good connecting, internet or phone. If you have any questions please do not hesitate to contact our producer at podcast@identifyingnelson.com.

How to join

The recording works best if you are able to join via the computer. We also provide a phone number in case that is not possible.

1) Join on a computer by following this link and installing the Goto Meeting software. It should take between 2 to 5 minutes.

https://global.gotomeeting.com/join/843055461

2) Headphones are recommended, but you can also use the computer’s microphone and speakers.

3) If you prefer to use a telephone you can join using the number and access code below.

Dial: +1 (805) 309–0033

Access Code: 843–055–461

4) You can also join from your iPhone®, iPad®, Android® or Windows Phone® device via the GoToMeeting app.

5) As a backup, in case you are having any problems, Nelson’s cell phone is: +1 (617) 967–3904

posts.title: What to expect as a guest on Inside the Journey
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[["html",{"html":"

What to expect as a guest on the Inside the Journey podcast

Thank you for being a guest on our show

We put together this page to tell you everything you need to know about being a guest on our show. If you have any questions, that are not answered on this page, please do not hesitate to contact our producer at podcast@identifyingnelson.com.

How long it will take

This year we are producing 20–30 minute episodes which are pre-recorded, edited, and released every other Sunday morning. The recording usually lasts 30–45 minutes, but we schedule hour long blocks to give us some wiggle room. We will email you a link to the show when it is live.

How to join

The recording works best if you are able to join via the computer. We also provide a phone number in case that is not possible. You can join the recording from work or home as long as you have a good connection (internet or phone).

1) Join on a computer by following this link and installing the Goto Meeting software. It should take between 2 to 5 minutes.

https://global.gotomeeting.com/join/843055461

2) Headphones are recommended, but you can also use the computer’s microphone and speakers.

3) If you prefer to use a telephone you can join using the number and access code below.

Dial: +1 (805) 309–0033

Access Code: 843–055–461

4) You can also join from your iPhone®, iPad®, Android® or Windows Phone® device via the GoToMeeting app.

5) As a backup, in case you are having any problems, Nelson’s cell phone is: +1 (617) 967–3904

"}]],"markups":[],"sections":[[10,0],[1,"p",[]]]}

posts.title: 5 ways you can help launch our film on Kickstarter
posts.mobiledoc:
{"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[["html",{"html":"

5 ways you can help launch our film on Kickstarter!

About this page

Welcome to the Kickstarter pre-launch page for our upcoming documentary film Identifying Nelson/Buscando a Roberto. If you don’t know much about our film or were sent here by a friend, to learn more visit our about the film page. You can also watch the first eight minutes of the film using the link below.

One question John and I often get about the film is “how can I help?” We set up this page to give you five ways you can do just that. If five things seems overwhelming, numbers 1 and 2 are the most important. A big thank you to everyone who has supported us this far!

8-minute preview: link coming soon…

1) Save the date (30 Seconds)

The first 24 hours of a Kickstarter campaign are the most important, so if you are thinking of backing us please do so as close to Tuesday May 19th, 7AM EST as possible. Click on the link above or the widget below to add a reminder to your calendar.


MAY19

Kickstarter LaunchLocation: http://inbarfilm.com/ks
When: 7AM – 9 AM

19-05-2015 07:00:0019-05-2015 09:00:0015Identifying Nelson: Kickstarter LaunchBack the project and help spread the word!http://inbarfilm.com/ksNelson de Wittinfo@identifyingnelson.comhttp://www.facebook.com/events/160427380695693falseDD/MM/YYYY1

If you prefer an email reminder, just enter your address below and we will let you know when the project launches!

2) Sign up to share (4 Minutes)

To get the word out about our film, we are using a website called Thunderclap.it. When you sign up, a link to our Kickstarter page will automatically be posted on May 19th to your Facebook, Twitter, or Tumblr accounts*. This will help us make a big splash on launch day, and it makes the process of sharing our project much easier for you.

*We realize not everyone uses social media, so if you don’t use these services scroll down to option 5.

3) Review our project page (5 Minutes)

We have worked hard to make our Kickstarter page the best it can be, but sometimes we miss things. Look over our project page, and if you would like to leave feedback, use the “feedback box” located at the top of the page.

Questions to consider:

  • Are there any spelling mistakes?
  • Is anything confusing or unclear?
  • Is there anything you don’t like?

4) Join our Facebook group (30 Seconds)

By joining the Facebook group you will be helping us promote the film throughout the campaign. In the group we will be posting articles people have written about our project that you can share, like, or support.

5) Download the Action Kit (30 Seconds)

Do you know someone who might be interested in our film? Would you like to write about the film on your blog or website? The Action Kit provides you with everything you need to share our film with people you know. It contains template emails, film stills, and an overview of the film.

If you have any questions or need additional material email us at nelson@identifyingnelson.com

6) Join the Team (Bonus!)

Taking on a project like this is ALOT of work and we can’t do it alone. If you are interested in helping us launch this film and telling the stories of the disappeared, visit our join the team page.
